M.G.L. c. 215, \u00a7\u00a7 3, 6.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Honorable Court under Massachusetts General Laws (M.G.L.) c. 215, §§ 3, 6, and Supplemental Probate and Family Court Rule 26, as this action seeks modification of a prior custody judgment entered by this Court.

Supplemental Probate and Family Court Ru.raw_text: Supplemental Probate and Family Court Rule 26
Supplemental Probate and Family Court Ru.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Honorable Court under Massachusetts General Laws (M.G.L.) c. 215, §§ 3, 6, and Supplemental Probate and Family Court Rule 26, as this action seeks modification of a prior custody judgment entered by this Court.

M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28, a custody judgment may be modified if the Court finds that a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred and that modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.

M.G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20 similarly authorizes custody modification judgments where circumstances materially change.

M.G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 10(a).proposition: The material changes demonstrate that the circumstances underlying the original custody judgment have altered so substantially that continuation of the existing order no longer serves the best interests of the child, the standard mandated by M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and M.G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a).

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have repeatedly held that the standard for custody modification requires both a material change in circumstances and a showing that modification is in the child’s best interests.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: Yannas is an initial divorce/custody and removal case, not a post-judgment custody modification case. The opinion discusses the best-interests standard for custody and the ‘real advantage’ test for removal, but it does not articulate or apply a two-part standard requiring a material change in circumstances plus best interests for modification of an existing custody order. Therefore it does not support the proposition about the standard for custody modification.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The judge was warranted in concluding that physical custody in the wife was in the best interests of each child. … The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… the words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have repeatedly held that the standard for custody modification requires both a material change in circumstances and a showing that modification is in the child’s best interests.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly describes the governing statutory and case-law standard for custody modification as requiring both (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances and (2) that the modification be necessary or conducive to the child’s welfare or best interests. The court quotes G. L. c. 208, § 28, applies that two-part test, and reverses because there was no material and substantial change shown and no best-interests basis for changing custody. This directly aligns with the proposition about the standard repeatedly applied by the Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28 (‘the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have repeatedly held that the standard for custody modification requires both a material change in circumstances and a showing that modification is in the child’s best interests.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/relocation case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not a custody-modification standards case. While it contains language about ‘substantial change in circumstances’ in a quotation from the ALI Principles in a footnote, the court does not hold or state that Massachusetts custody modification requires both a material change in circumstances and a best-interests showing. Its operative standard here is only that removal must be in the child’s best interests, so it does not support the cited proposition about the general modification standard.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt:
The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part:

“(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances . . . only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce] ...

“(4) When a relocation constituting changed circumstances . . . renders it impractical to maintain the same proportion of custodial responsibility to each parent, the court should modify the parenting plan in accordance with the child’s best interests ...”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have repeatedly held that the standard for custody modification requires both a material change in circumstances and a showing that modification is in the child’s best interests.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: This case distinguishes between initial custody determinations under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), which use a pure “best interests of the child” standard, and modification proceedings under § 20, which require a substantial (material) change in circumstances. The SJC expressly declines to apply the modification standard here because the case was tried as an initial custody matter, not as a modification. Thus, while the opinion acknowledges the substantial-change standard for modifications, it does not itself hold that both a material change and best interests are required for custody modification; it simply describes § 20 in passing and finds it inapplicable.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … General Laws c. 209C, § 20, gives the Probate Court jurisdiction to modify an existing judgment for support, custody, or visitation. Such a modification should be made only if ‘a substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child has occurred.’”

Mazzone v. Mazzone, 429 Mass. 152 (1999).proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have repeatedly held that the standard for custody modification requires both a material change in circumstances and a showing that modification is in the child’s best interests.
Mazzone v. Mazzone, 429 Mass. 152 (1999).support_reasoning: The provided opinion is a Massachusetts criminal case (a murder conviction) and does not address custody, family law, or standards for custody modification. There is no discussion of “material change in circumstances” or “best interests of the child,” nor any modification standard. Therefore, this citation does not support the claimed proposition about custody modification standards.

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have repeatedly held that the standard for custody modification requires both a material change in circumstances and a showing that modification is in the child’s best interests.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: This opinion concerns initial care, protection, and adoption placement decisions, applying a pure best interests standard under G.L. c. 210, § 3 and related statutes. It does not address or articulate the specific standard for modification of an existing custody order, nor does it discuss any requirement of both a material change in circumstances and best interests as a threshold for modification. Therefore it does not provide authority for the claimed custody‑modification proposition.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: "Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c)."

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have repeatedly held that the standard for custody modification requires both a material change in circumstances and a showing that modification is in the child’s best interests.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the statutory standard for modifying custody orders under G.L. c. 208, § 28, and applies it, requiring both (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances and (2) that the modification be necessary in the best interests of the child. Although the primary issue in Rosenberg is child support, the court directly discusses and applies the custody-modification standard, thus supporting the proposition that the SJC requires both elements for custody modification.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].’”

Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have repeatedly held that the standard for custody modification requires both a material change in circumstances and a showing that modification is in the child’s best interests.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the governing standard for an initial custody determination—stating that the controlling consideration is the welfare of the child—and affirms the probate judge’s discretionary decision on that basis. It does not articulate or apply a two-part standard requiring (1) a material change in circumstances and (2) best interests for modification of an existing custody order. The only reference to modification is a brief citation to G. L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 30 and another case, without describing any specific ‘material change’ requirement, so the case does not support the proposition as stated.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).relevant_excerpt: “The material facts found and reported by the judge support his action in awarding custody of the child to the father and stepmother with no rights of visitation by the mother. In Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930), we stated the basic rule applicable in such cases as follows: ‘The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child….’ … We hold that the judge correctly applied these principles in deciding this case… As to the circumstances in which orders for the custody of minor children may be subject to future modification by the court see G. L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 30…”}

Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.raw_text: Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 (2006)
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have repeatedly held that the standard for custody modification requires both a material change in circumstances and a showing that modification is in the child’s best interests.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly quotes and applies G. L. c. 208, § 28, stating that modification of custody orders after divorce requires (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances and (2) that the modification be necessary in the best interests of the children. Although the case is primarily a removal case, the court directly recites and relies on this two‑part modification standard, thereby supporting the proposition about the established Massachusetts standard for custody modification.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.relevant_excerpt: “He concluded from this that any change in circumstances occurred prior to the divorce, and therefore did not justify a modification. His ruling is inconsistent with G. L. c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, § 60 (‘Upon a complaint after a divorce … , the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”

Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have repeatedly held that the standard for custody modification requires both a material change in circumstances and a showing that modification is in the child’s best interests.
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).support_reasoning: The opinion briefly addresses custody procedure only to say that a change in a custody judgment should be sought via a complaint for modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28, but it does not articulate or apply any substantive standard requiring both a material change in circumstances and that modification be in the child’s best interests. The court’s discussion focuses on the impropriety of altering custody by motion and does not set out or reaffirm the two-prong modification standard claimed in the proposition.
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “A change in a custody judgment, however, should be made pursuant to a complaint for modification under G. L. c. 208, § 28. If the judge felt that joint legal custody put the children at risk, or was not in their best interests, because of the wife’s worrisome parenting behavior, then the judge should have ordered sole legal custody to the father. She did not have discretion to fashion, even with the agreement of both parents, an alternative plan.”
